posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

Same. Watched a bunch of Gixxerbrah and other vids, wanted bike since I was young (dad has a couple SuperSports). Saw plenty of accidents and problem vids, wasn't super confident. Stick to the standard tyre sizes. Suzuki knows better than some average-IQ retard on an internet forum.
According to a quick google search, your tyre sizes are: front 120/70-17, rear 140/70-17; just stick with that. posts.com: Can you air cool an engine by driving it around winter temps with the hood removed?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How can a Hoosier such as myself renew an expired driver's license with no utility bills to use as proof of address?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26156267
no, because the cylinders are well insulated from the exterior surface of the engine by the void cast into the engine which is called the "water jacket". cylinders in a water cooled engine lack the ability to transfer heat away unless in direct contact with water/coolant. also, the cylinder head depends on coolant passages as well, since it doesn't have enough surface area to lose heat via radiation or convection. keep in mind that the specific heat of water is much higher than that of air, meaning water can absorb and transfer heat much more efficiently than air. water cooling is considered better since you can easily maintain a controlled and uniform temperature throughout the engine, and it's easier to design a large powerful engine when you don't have to account for bulky external cooling fins.

an air cooled engine has the cylinder in close contact with the exterior of the engine, which is finned like a heat sink for air to be blown across. main advantage being simplicity, as there's no "cooling system" that can fail and leave you stranded (coolant leaks out, water pump belt breaks, etc) but the operating temperature of the engine is harder to control for different operating environments and loads, so the engine life is relatively shorter, and specific power output is relatively lower.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26156267
ideally the radiators for water and oil cooling should have access to fresh air from outside of the engine bay, and dump their heat outside of the engine bay.
radiators can be remotely mounted .ie with longer tubes to position them more for better airflow. (don't ask me about pump head pressure tho lmao)
and proper use of ducting can prevent debris and insects from building up on the radiators.

other parts in the engine bay are air cooled and more confined in their access to fresh air, .eg fuel rails, fuse boxes, coil packs, alternator, battery
such parts are more dependant on the engine bays ambient temperature, but passive ventilation such as hood vents may be sufficient
but water and dust must be kept away from delicate components, so the vents should be placed with great care.

since you are driving in winter some of your engines parts may become too cold, or too wet. many older cars include muffs and baffles to deal with winter conditions.
and particularly in winter you must make sure that when you are stuck in traffic or driving up hill that your cars main ventilation fan is working,
I had an electric radiator fan whose thermostat had burnt out from being overworked, later replaced with a manual switch as a quick fix.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26156478
yeah but those trucks and your explorer were full of coolant being constantly circulated by the water pump thru the engine & heater core, even with the thermostat closed. if you couldn't get cabin heat at -10 your thermostat is stuck open, or heater core is blocked.

the outcome of driving with no coolant depends on the specific engine i suppose, but eventually it will get too hot to run and start pinging and knocking heavily. not uncommon to scuff pistons, blow head gaskets, warp/crack cylinder heads due to extremely localized overheating of pistons, bores and exhaust ports. note that peak combustion temperature in a gasoline engine can reach 4000F while the melting temperature of aluminum is only 1200F.

i remember riding a friends honda shadow for more than half an hour without realizing the cooling system was completely dry. ran fine until i slowed down for traffic, then it started pinging really bad and died, would just ping and kick back when trying to start. the temperature gauge stayed in the middle the whole time lol

>>26163077
>It's a really odd smell not related to anything in the car.
my money would be your evaporator drain is clogged and water is sitting in the evap pan and developing mold. find the drain hose and blow it out with compressed air then run some cleaner like simplegreen through the system to clean up the mold.
> do some car condensers for the A/C actually rumble harder than the engin
Your condensor is the radiator like thing on the front of the car and shouldnt make any noise, you're probably thinking of your compressor, the thing that spins attached to the engine. no, it is not normal for it to be vibrating, most likely it is failing and i would replace it before it gets metal shavings throughout your entire AC system, if it hasnt already

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26165418
It was so common in the early-mid '00s that you could rice a whole car out with one trip to Pep Boys. They had aluminum GT wings (usually comically undersized), knockoff Sparco seats, underglow, fake vents and scoops, hideous shift knobs, steering wheels, and clamp-on pedals, and various bodyside graphics sold rolled up, and if you had one of the really popular ricing platforms like an EG Civic or DC Integra you could even get application-specific stuff like lowering springs, clear taillights, and I think even bodykits at some locations. (Mine had a few on display but I'm not sure if you could actually buy them off the shelf or if it was just showing that you could special order them.)
Virtually everything was from this "APC" brand that's apparently been dead since '09, hard to even find pics of their shit anymore (and I wish I could come up with one of the ricer aisle at Pep's because it was hilarious) but this one will probably bring back some memories among my fellow 3x year old boomers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

Yep, was definitely a thing. My dad took me to Sydney Show and Shine in 2004 and man it was wild. Everything was chrome and the place smelled like kebabs. I remember dad pointing out that most turbo kits fabbed on these cars didn't even run vacuum lines or oil/water feed - it was bolted on the day and all for show. If your first car was in the style of pic related in those days then you were king shit. I remember seeing chromed out Lancers, Civics, Skylines and Silvias everywhere with flame stickers and sound systems heavier than the car and being so jealous of how cool they were. This was also when you could pick up an R33 Skyline in turbo manual for less than $4k. It was a simpler time indeed.

After you turn the engine off you're supposed to keep your foot on the brake until the handbrake is on, so that way the car doesn't do the little rock and roll on the drivetrain that will happen if you let the brake off when stopped in gear. >>26162765
Yes it does. Depending on the engine rotating it backwards can cause damage.
Some engines are very prone to slipping if they are rotatet backwards, because of a long tensioner stroke, or the angle between the crank and first cam gear combined with the slack in an untentioned chain.
In general when you work on engines rotating them backwards beyond adjusting position etc is better to be avoided.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How do you guys center stickers? Like if I want to center one on my rear windshield, any tricks/tips?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164256
Use a piece of cord*. upper left corner to lower right corner. Mark the approximate center with a liquid chalk pen or something else thats easily removable.
Repeat between upper right corner to lower left corner. X now marks the exact center of your windshield.
*Cord because modern windshields aren't flat surfaces. Cord follows the form.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164262
After that you measure height and width of your sticker. Divide both values by 2 and you got the center of your stigger too
For example:
Sticker width is 10 inches then 5 inches is the center.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164262
Alternatively you can use masking tape instead of cord. Either way: Don't get distracted by the fact you won't see a straight line. That's due to the mentioned curvature of the windshield.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164964
From a technical point of view, the inline-8 has a very long engine block, and a very long crankshaft to go with it.

A long crankshaft requires a lot heavier construction to get it stiff enough to resist flex and vibration, the same with the block. With that heavier crankshaft, also comes larger rotating inertia: it’s less responsive to throttle inputs.

This car has inline-8.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: With any reasonable amount of torque the crank deforms.

posts.com: I-8s are often inherently harmonically-balanced.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Because a 90 degree V twin has almost perfect mechanical balance, if not an even firing order. Now make 4 of those and you get a near perfect balance with an even firing order.

A v8 technically has better balance than an inline 6 assuming they are all counterweighted.

one of the few annoyances with the Pentastar is that it runs hot for NOX emissions but has all this fiber plastic crap in places where high heat is present.
my recommendation for op is get the Mishimoto or Ripp 180 deg. thermostat, it keeps the engine a whole 40 degrees cooler because it actually opens at 180, as opposed to the OEM one which is supposed to open at 195 but doesn't fully open till 205 and frequently gets stuck and won't open until 230+, which doesn't not throw a code and you won't notice it intermittently overheating until it actually does.
also, the oil cooler, crossover tube, and thermostat elbow can be replaced with metal parts if desired. the dorman oe-fix oil cooler is all over amazon, the crossover tube is another one of their oe-fix parts, and the metal thermostat elbow can be acquired from a V6 Ram 1500.

Oil changes are a great way to start breaking down the mystery of cars and engines. I had a dad but he was absolute shit at anything mechanical or tool oriented. We blew up so many B&S mowers and I have no idea how and he never wrenched on any of the 8+ cars we went through as a kid. I failed to launch on basic car stuff for years. Just put the bolt back and tighten half a turn after finger tight and once you put oil in the car, check and make sure there's not leaks on the filter or plug.

CLEAN YOUR GODDAMN FLOORMATS.

A 350ci pulls about 450cfm @ 5k rpm.
Of course going to 6k or 7k makes a major difference- but if you don't rev that high then you're losing torque and responsiveness for a paper tiger.
Over carb'ing and engine is one of the oldest and biggest mistakes that just keeps biting people in the ass.

posts.name: Mitchell
posts.com:
>>26160856
I went and looked it up. Apparently the 2-speeds were already out of production before 1966, since there's no mention of them in my 1972 Motor's, which lists:
>C4 dual-range automatic
>C4 dual-range semi-automatic ('70/71 Maverick only)
>C6 dual-range automatic
>Cruise-o-Matic
>Ford-o-Matic three-speed
>Merc-o-Matic three-speed

From what I can tell, these are all three-speed transmissions, the "dual-range" refers to the D1/D2 or D/D-dot on the shifter. I don't know why the C6 is labelled as such.
The C4 has a green dot before 1967. The C4 was also never behind anything larger than a 351.
The others are labeled D1/D2 until 1967, except the C6 which was always P-R-N-D-2-1.

TL;DR now that I've worked through this confusing mess, it's entirely possible that's not the original transmission.

posts.name: Mitchell
posts.com:
>>26160979
The C* were weight reduction and (probably) cost reduction.
The FX and MX were cast iron Borg-Warner units, made up until 1968 or so, after which they were merged into the (still cast iron) FMX.
The C4 I think was meant to replace the FX, same with the C6/MX, but there was likely some contract fuckery going on at the time.
What's goofy is that after 1969, the FMX was put behind the Windsors and 240s. It must have been an beefier alternative to the C4.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26161019
From what I recall from doing a 6 cyl to v8 swap for a friend in his 68 Falcon, Ford was sweating in the late 50’s/ early 60’s because GM and Chrysler both had a fairly good automatic for their lineup. One of the powertrain guy mentioned this to a new guy who was just hired from Borg Warner. He told them that they had a fairly strong 3 speed, ready to go. They bought them from bw early on and then purchased the rights to build them their self later. The be units were sold to manufacturers like Volvo and maybe Studebaker and Kaiser. It’s a pretty cool design and because the case bolts to the bell housing is very adaptable to a wide range of engines with just a bell housing swap. Mom had a 78 wagon with 351M that had one behind it.

>>26160974
The shift pattern is independent of the transmission itself and is a function of the valve body. Some transmissions have multiple shift patterns available depending on application. So many different transmissions can be swapped and the valve body changed over to match the shift pattern on the column/console.
Identification is done by pan bolt pattern and servo placement.
FX was medium duty, MX was heavy duty.
FMX combined aspects of both to create a single option to eliminate redundant production lines, which was later dropped completely for C6 which was cheaper and simpler.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26163649
Yea I’ve done a shit load of suspension work marking cams and eccentrics with sharpies and shit and counting turns on tie rods and it’s still usually at least a little sketch. Home system seemed really easy and straightforward, pretty much exactly like doing it in the hunter machine except manually
>place car on turn plates
>mount jigs onto wheels and level vertically and horizontally with bubble gauges
>zero digital gauge on pavement right in front of contact patch to compensate for floor unevenness
>mount gauge onto jig, which is now a live camber reading
>to measure caster, turn steering wheel to 20 degrees marked on turn plate, zero gauge there, then then turn all the way past zero to twenty the other way. Gauge is now displaying caster (you’ve effectively done a caster sweep).
>toe is checked using the tape measures on the front and rear of the jig
>adjust caster, then camber, then toe
Only thing I don’t like is the toe measurement, it’s just the total toe for the whole axle not individual wheel toe. And, it’s in inches. So say my spec is 1/16th toe in and my actual reading is 5/8” toe in, that just tells me my total toe is off but not at which wheel or by how much. So I’d have to string check the car to figure out which wheel is off by how much, and then check the rear toe as well to make sure i don’t end up with some crazy thrust angle problem or something. It’s def gonna be a lot of trial and error. My coworker used to do alignments with string and bubble gauges back like 50 years ago and he said it’s not too hard once you get the hang of it so I guess we’ll see.

>>26166552
Yeah there's a lot of people who work on Volkswagens and don't know a lot of the important stuff. My engine builder used stock heater boxes on a 1904cc engine with bigger valves that revs to about 6,200 and once I started researching stuff on the samba I realized that that's not a good combo. The one on the right in this picture is a stock heater box exhaust tube, you can see it's actually an unusual shape inside to get more surface area for heat exchanging but it's not good for flow unless you have a stock or mild engine. A lot of people leave off the hoover bit on the oil cooler which is actually important for sealing it to the shroud, or run 20w50 even though that's too heavy and the cooler won't work as well. Definitely start reading up and learning everything you can.

So my mom came home from a bad day at work and asked me to make her a mug cake. I said for sure, and made her one. I was in a rush because I knew she wanted to go sit down, and I forgot to make the miniature batch of icing that goes on top. I handed it to her, told her it was hot, and she asked where the icing was. I sprinted back into the kitchen with socks on for extra boost, and made the icing really quick. I slid back into our living room and handed it to her, and she told me, "wow that was fast!"

Then I said the fatal line, my ultimate demise.

"I'M FAST AS FUCK BOI"

The room goes quiet. I can feel the verbal beating I'm about to get. My mom tells me I'm grounded for a week and the only reason it's not two is because the mug cake is really good and she does appreciate it. So now I'm pretending to do homework but instead I'm writing this.

TL:DR accidentally cussed in front of my parents, grounded for a week

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26152946
The T300 is a fairly good wheel, but ideally you should pick one up second hand to save a bit of money. It's worth paying a little more for one with T-LCM pedals instead, they're better than the defaults.

The shifter is a waste of time. If you need one, get the chink one for 50 bucks off aliexpress or probably dropshipped to Amazon, or if you know how to use a soldering iron you can pick up an old G25/27 one and an arduino for 20 bucks. Only reason to buy the TM shifter is if you really want one and you're only playing on console, where you can't plug in multiple devices.

As for the seat, personally I wouldn't bother for a T300. Sure, you can get one, but it's going to be an extra 100-200 bucks and not really be that good, screwing the pedals down to a bit of wood and lashing them to your office chair will be fine and any old desk you've got is good enough for the wheelbase. If you have to get something and you really want the adjustment, the wheel stand 2.0 from NLR is a pretty good choice and it wouldn't be hard to bolt a seat onto it later.

>>26165183
Definitely NFS Heat with some simple mods if you just want visual customization, if you want a cheaper or free game with more open modding, try Street Legal Racing Redline, it's the classic rice sim.

BeamNG is good and works with Automation to let you actually drive the cars you build in it. Automation by itself is kind of an autistic grand strategy game involving the auto industry rather than a real driving game or simulator. On the other hand BeamNG by itself has no actual "game" to get in the way of it's god-tier simulation and can do lots of things other than cars like planes, helicopters, and boats with the same physics the cars operate on. Some cars can even equip wings and JATO rockets to take to the skies regardless.
Downside to Beam is to make cars from scratch for it takes a huge amount of effort and autism so cars people have converted from other games tend to be janky and look like shit while the same process in Assetto Corsa is worth $10 a month on Patreon.

The current through the warning light bulb powers the exiter windings of the alternator. When the alternator starts charging it excites itself and the warning light goes out since no more current flows. With an LED in the dash not enough current was flowing to the exciter winding so the alt would never start charging.
Also the guy was me all along.

Are you really trying to tell me car culture died because your meme double wishbones stopped being put on most cars? Do you actually understand what a trivial difference it makes unless you're going 10/10 on a racetrack as an expert driver?

It died because in 08 loans got way harder to get and Cash for Clunkers gutted all the cheap project cars. When loans were easy, people bought new cars all the time and therefore sold off their old cars, which kept a deflated used market. People had also not yet figured out how reliable and long lasting fuel injected cars were without constant attention that carburetors needed, so they saw used cars as cars with one foot in the grave. Look at the difference in availability of 600cc sportbikes on FB Marketplace between about 04/05 when they first became fuel injected and 08 when the crash happened and compare it to any bikes since. You will see like 75% 05-08 bikes and barely any older (bc carbs) or newer (bc harder to get loans).

We lived in an artificially prosperous era that we'll probably never see again.

>>26132608
I had one for a decade without any issues with a d17a2 and the bmxa automatic transmission. Only changed the valve cover gasket and cam plug. Brought it into the 160k mile range when i get rid of it. Besides gasket failure 10 years and 150k miles is mostly normal even for old d16 and d15 platforms. Its just what age and abuse do. I will say the head is a pain in the ass about thread stripping the valve cover bolts at hand tightness. Also ac going bad is again normally an issue a few decades after built if its still on oem. People like to act like everything from the 90s before it didn't also require bare minimal maintenance and have parts degrade with age anymore for some reason. Besides if we want to compleain about anything for this gen the si had bad snchros stock and the reorientation of the engine makes it a bitch to work on also power steering fluid in everything in the 2000s were shit.
Tbf my current fc4 is more of a pain in the ass in ac failure. On second evap core and 3rd condenser. Paint chips worse than any civic I've owned and is fading harder than the 9th gen I had that got paint recalled. Em2 gave me less problems somehow.

the facelift from 2006 to 2008 has a few improvements like a revised aux belt route that won't eat pulley and alternator bearings, exhaust manifold replaced under warranty with a cast one that doesn't crack, larger front brakes and a bunch of other little things, but both are solid cars.

>>26156404
Driving an R56 these days and it fucking sucks. Had it for 3 months and here's the report:
-PO put fucking autozone tier union jacks everywhere. on the hatch, and all the valve stem caps
-Burns 3L/1000mi oil. Yes, I replaced the PCV already, still has the issue
-VANOS fucks up, horrible misfires (also probably due to the burning oil)
-14mm 12 point spark plugs (great now I need to buy a specialty tool just for fucking changing plugs on a temporary shitbox?)
-Uncomfortable; pedals are too far back due to "packaging", sun visors have 1 inch gap between the A pillar and visor, and the shitty excuse of a side visor doesn't go back far enough to actually block the sun from hitting the side of your face.
-Lower rad hose has shitty clips holding it in place, they came undone and dragged the hose until it leaked
-Checking coolant temp (no gauge) requires a 5 minute dance with the button on the tach display that involves adding the last 5 digits of the VIN... every single time you want to see the temp
-Temp is between 100-110C at all times because fuck engine longevity right mate, it's all about #efficiency
-#efficiency 35mpg, but requires premium so any real fuel cost savings are out the window
-Shifter at the transmission had its bolt literally just back out for no reason. Fucking limeys didn't use loctite or proper torque over in Oxford.
I had an R53 Cooper S and that one was fine. Good modern suspension was very predictable on track. Good power delivery. Only downside was every time I had to work on it it was satan due to tight packaging. The nonturbo R56 at least has some room to work in the engine bay.

>>26135292
I used to do this as a high school job. We very rarely fucked with the coiling on anything but starters for big diesels. Not much actually goes wrong with them. Crack it open, replace or rebuild the solenoid, replace the drive if it’s shot, new bushings/bearings, fresh grease and they almost always work.

Weakest point is the solenoid contacts. Usually they’re the first thing to wear out.

>>26129723
I am currently chasing down a couple of issues on my newly acquired '97 F150.
>shifter
I've got a shift indicator that isn't indicating the correct gear and there's a squeaking/plasticy grinding noise when moving the shift lever down through the gears. So far I've replaced the shifter shaft bushings, shifter shaft clamps (the good ole boy I bought it from replaced on of the clamps with an ill-fitting strip of 20GA at some point so that cleaned up the shifter slop considerably), replaced the shifter and retaining pin along with adding a damper to further cut down on slop, blue Loctite'd all the fasteners in the shifter mechanism and torqued to spec, and I've checked the PRNDL mechanism to make sure it is functioning correctly. All of this has improved the feel of the shifter considerably, but no dice on the incorrect indicator and squeaky noise. Through process of elimination I am now convinced that the shift cable needs to be adjusted or replaced. I can watch the mechanism move from the floor and there is no slop. The noise seems to come from close to the firewall where the cable is. Like it is binding up or something.
>heater
I have no heat. I replaced the thermostat and in doing so realized the coolant system badly needs flushed. There's no air in the system so far as I can tell. The vents are blowing cold air so I narrowed the problem down to either a faulty blend knob, blend door actuator, or blend door. Today I removed the blend actuator to test functionality and further narrow down the problem. It functioned when turning the knob so the knob and actuator both work. Around the key that the actuator turns there is black plastic debris which I believe indicates a broken blend door. Tomorrow I am going to be cutting through the dash and plenum behind the glovebox and replacing the door. My hope is that between a coolant system flush, a heater core backflush, a new blend door actuator, and a new blend door heat to the cab can be restored.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26150528
I'm the guy that recc'd the chief. Before buying another tool you should make sure your compressor isn't getting cucked by 1/4" fittings and the shitty regulator. Highly recommend replacing all fittings and couplers with 3/8 ends with 1/4 npt threads and a 3/8 regulator. Make sure your hose is 3/8 too. No reason to go to 1/2 as it is too big for not that much gain.

Some shit is easier on certain cars, some shit is harder. Inline engine only has one bank of cylinders so easier for headgaskets and stuff, but an I-6 could have stuff buried behind the firewall. Transverse engines mean you have to go in from the wheel well to do lots of the accessories and belt.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26130254
I know I'm more than a week late to be updating this blog. But I managed to remove the old throttle cables with a combination of ring spanners, poking utensils and what girls refer to as 'magic hands'. My original plan to just replace the internal cable was foiled by the damaged English (oxford) and their refusal to include any of the cable ends that LITERALLY EVERY SINGLE JAPANESE BIKE USES in their "universal throttle cable kit". Luckily I'm God's favourite NPC so the go to bike bits shop had two (almost) universal throttle cable kits that ( were Japanese and) they sold for the price of one because I was wearing overalls and told them I ride a tiny Honda. I say 'almost universal because while my throttle housing had one M8×1.25 thread that fitted perfectly the throttle return is a M10× 1.25 thread, I figured out I could just drill and tap the end of the old cable. However the only way to buy a M10×1.25 tap on a Sunday is as part of a 40 piece tap and die set at any given hardware store.
But after all of this and some more 'Magic hands' I have a fully functioning bike with zero throttle slack. Those "universal" cables were a mm or two short, so if you as much as breathe on the throttle it revs to 6k. There's no excess tension on the cable it's somehow perfectly to length. And it's great, she feels more responsive than ever, in fact it's soo much better I've almost stopped complaining about the final drive ratio being too short.
Anyway good luck with your oil changes or whatever.

>>26161880
I helped a friend stick an LS into his 95, you can actually very easily convert a DBW to DBC - you need to
>1: Add in the bosses into the intake manifold for the throttle cable bracket OR get a DBC intake. You can steal the nutserts from a junkyard truck and then stick them into your DBW intake which is what we did.
>2: Get a DBC throttle body. If you use a DBW intake manifold, remove the PCV fitting from it and plug the hole.
>3: Run the ISV and TPS wires to the correct pins in the ECU as you would a DBC - you need to get creative with I think 2 of the ground pins - we just used another ground pin that was unused in the ECU that did the same thing.
>4: Tune the ECU such that ETC is disabled (literally 1 bit in the tune haha)
>5: Winrar
As I understand it the DBW ECUs (P59) are preferible to the DBC (P01?) since they support greater tuning options and flex fuel support, in our case we simply used the DBW setup since the 5.3 we used came from an 04 avalanche and it was all included with the junkyard engine (fucking $200!)
We still need to tune out the auto trans code since he's running an NV4500, but it seems to be working for him so far.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26162695
Oh yeah I wanted to add the early chevy DBW is hardly a modern interpretation of DBW at all - the throttle and gas pedal talk through the throttle control module with the ECU also talking to it to limit throttle angle - the ECU itself acts very much like a DBC in that sense, only telling the throttle control module things like to limit torque when going too fast/limiter/transmission protection etc. It's not like modern DBW where the entire pedal angle->torque request->add in loss torque->engine load->manifold pressure->throttle angle process is done in the ECU and needs to all work correctly. That's why you can simply tune out DBW on your junkyard LS

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26162716
You need to hook up a scan tool and find out which cylinder(s) are misfiring. If it's just one or two, swap those plugs and coils (or wires if older car) with another cylinder. If the misfire moves to the cylinder you swapped with you know it's either your coil or plugs and you can swap those to narrow it down. If the misfire doesn't move, it's either your harness or a mechanical problem with the cylinder and you can troubleshoot from there.

>>26163519

>>26164907
ok, spray all the spark plug wires down with water, run the car in the dark. does the misfire get worse when wet? do you see little spark flashes from the wires? if so definitely bad wires. also inspect your spark plugs, if one or more is more fouled or if there are carbon tracks that indicates a problem specifically in that cylinder or with that plug.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26162716
>>26164911
>Since I am able to smell unburnt gas out of the exhaust, would I be able to rule out an injector problem?
and not necessarily, a leaking injector will overfuel the cylinder causing it to misfire and stinking up the exhaust. the typical way to check for this is run your engine with a fuel press gauge attached. does the pressure drop rapidly after you switch it off? if so probable stuck injector.

>>26158307
The mods you've listed are very achievable. You can definitely do them all on your own as a newb if you put your mind to it. A 350z with coilovers and tyres is faster than many many other cars on the twisties. It doesn't really do straight line speed, but it'll grip and pull and go very nicely around corners.

Definitely do a lightened flywheel, they shift like SHIT from 1st to 2nd.
And they definitely burn oil. This is mostly due to its pcv valve being fucky (look up z33 pcv valve for more info) so you can mostly solve it with an oil catch can. The engines aren't camry invincible, but they're really quite reliable for what they are.

If you're a hackerman sounds like upgrading things like the interior would be up your alley. And boy is the z33 the car for that. The interior is fucking hideous. A custom head unit would be fun.

All in all I think the z33 is a great car if you want something that looks cool that you can modify. It's probably just starting to increase in value as it ages and it's not too old that parts are impossible to find.

Comparable cars would be:
toyota gt86 if you want something very slow
mazda miata if you are gay
golf gti if you want straight line speed and you are a scumbag
newer honda integra if you wany something slow AND fwd

>>26163758
OP, how did you manage to expose the back sides of your OGM speakers if you seem to be too dumb to even open a can of dogfood without hurting yourself?

1) Grab each of the spade connectors. Not their cables but the connectors themselves. Wiggle a little while you're pulling. If it doesnt work, use a pair of needle-nose pliers or something

2) Use pliers to cut off the spade connectors. Then remove about 1/2 to 1 inch of the insulation.

3) Twist the respective wiring so they stay connected and no single braids stick out

4) Fold the exposed wiring to the back to give the entire exposed copper double thickness

5) Put this part into the slightly unscrewed connectors of your new speakers. Tighten the screws again and test if your cables sit tight

This is the quick and dirty way. But it will work. I guess you're too dumb to crimp ring connectors onto your cables or something so let's do it this way

People don't understand how much of a shithole USSR was and Russia is.
In the USSR when you got married the state gave you a car for your honeymoon.
It was just for the honeymoon. When the honeymoon was over they took the car back.
My Russian high-school teacher was a translator for the Russian vice president (this was like '93 or something).
He showed him a Walmart and the VP thought it was propaganda bullshit, that the store was filled with items and people shopping just for him to see.
When my teacher showed him my school he didn't understand why there were so many cars. When he was told they were the students he refused to believe that kids had their own cars.

Russians were content with the Lada because just owning a car was an amazing feat in life.

>>26166270
Oh that's not hard actually.
Cadillac exemplified the size-era of luxury auto manufacturing, typically thought of as the period between WWII and 1980.
The post-war economic boon for Americans combined with rapidly scaling infrastructure came together to create the huge, beautiful, and powerful cars that dominated the US market in the 1960s and 1970s.
A whole host of factors relating to emissions, fuel consumption, and economic conditions all brought the size-era to an end, as small economical cars took hold in the American markets in the late 1970s.

1977 was the death of Cadillac, and GM's end to the size-era.

Post-war Cadillac is the Cadillac people remember, and their focus was on luxury and scale.
From 1945 to 1976, Cadillac made their cars bigger, better, faster, and that's all they did.
Add chrome, add cubes, add features, rinse and repeat for 30 years.
Auto-dimming headlamps, self-leveling suspension, power seats with memory settings, dual-reservoir brakes, automatic climate control, bulb-out indicators, Caddies were bad motherfuckers.
The cars themselves just kept getting bigger, with the Sedan de Ville breaking the 230" (19ft 2") mark, and the Series 75, sometimes mistakenly referred to as the Fleetwood, reaching a staggering 252" (21ft) in length.

(1/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26166431
At one time, Cadillac was the king of V8 engines.
The first production V8 in a vehicle was a Cadillac L-Head V8. Cadillac also produced the very first American V8 with a cross-plane crankshaft in 1924.
Post-war, Cadillac's OHV V8 design would become the basis for countless other GM engines.
Chevrolet small-block, big-block, and LS engines can all be traced back to the Cadillac OHV engine that earned them Motor Trend Car of The Year in 1949.
Conditions in the 1960s allowed for rapid increases in engine size and capacity.
From 1968 onward, 472 and 500 cubic inch engines become the norm for Cadillac, that's 7.7L - 8.2L.
In 1972 and 1973, the first automotive emissions regulations were put into place in the United States, thus beginning the malaise period of automotive design, and putting the first big nail in the Cadillac coffin.

In 1970, a Cadillac with the 500 cube V8 was putting out over 400 horsepower and over 550 ft lbs of torque, and in the 4,900lb de Ville could net you 12 miles per gallon.
By 1976, changes required to meet emissions brought the massive 8.2L V8 down to a pitiful 190 horsepower and only 360 ft lbs of torque, powering the now 5,400lb de Ville and getting only 8 miles per gallon.
During this time, the cars were still getting larger and more luxurious, with more features being added to distract from the steadily decreasing power and fuel economy.


(2/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26166434

A combination of increasing emissions standards, safety standards, and demands for fuel-economy from consumers who had now lived through the 1973 Gas Crisis, all pushed GM to bring an end to the size-era.
30 years of pushing bigger, faster, more luxurious vehicles had finally caught up with the reality of changing global economic conditions.
In 1977, GM began to downsize their vehicles, including the entire Cadillac line-up.
The 1977 DeVille and Fleetwood both featured a smaller 425 cubic inch V8 motor, they both rode on the shorter DeVille chassis.
They were shorter, narrower, and half a ton lighter than they had been before.

From 1977 to the re-birth of Cadillac in 1991, their vehicles continued to become smaller and simpler.
The lists of features stopped growing, as other automakers were catching up or passing them.
No longer was Cadillac home to GM's largest and most powerful engines.
No longer was Cadillac allowed to run rampant with design, the chrome and fins that once defined the appearance of the brand were slowly lost.

The first post-size-era Cadillac was the 1981 Cimarron, the first compact from the brand, and widely regarded as one of the worst vehicles in American automotive history.
Cadillac would continue to fail sideways through the 1980s, and it took the 1991 introduction of the Northstar to revitalize the brand and set the stage for Cadillac as it exists today.

(3/3)

If you'd like to learn more about the size-era, the malaise period, and the distinct global economic conditions that caused them, I'd recommend reading about the US dollar crisis, and the Bretton Woods system. Fun stuff, for white people anyway.

>>26159089
These have a roll bar because they have seat belts, but many argue it's better to have neither and be thrown clear in an accident.

The bumpers aren't to "protect the tires", it's to prevent tire to tire contact that can result in an accident that looks exactly like this.

Fire suits aren't necessary because you aren't in a caged car, don't carry much fuel, and any fire that would start could be put out easily by a trackside steward or even a bucket of water. It's not uncommon to wear skid-resistant coveralls, but situations where you are thrown from the kart and slide are rare in rentals like this.

Idiots ruin everything, I've seen tons of crazy shit because people refuse to recognize the danger they put themselves and everyone else in. The worst, apparently, are young girls, they tend to freeze up with their foot flat to the floor and close their eyes and send it into a fence and have to get taken away in an ambulance.

Get whatever bike you think looks cool but also suits your practical needs for travel and comfort. You will have to compromise the looks for practicality and vice versa. 400 sport bike is good beginner territory. Riding long distances can be done on sport bikes but it's generally better to have a cruiser/adv bike for that.

You're going to have to go sit on some bikes and see how they feel to you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26165988
Pay no attention to 26165993 He is the one without taste.
The ninja is a perfectly fine bike. I've still got my learner, a n400 and it was a perfectly acceptable bike. The only issue I've had with it is that chain tensioning is a bitch. You can't use the swing arm hash marks for alignment, you need to actually measure from the end of the adjuster bolt to the plate. The vulcan is also a perfectly capable cruiser, easily matching in performance to most harleys and other cruisers while having vastly better build quality than harley.
The rebel I'm not a big fan on, I'm 6'2" and its a squeeze to get on, but same can be said about my ninja just to a much lesser degree.
If you plan on riding with your friend a lot and his group, its very likely that his group is all cruisers if those were the recommendations he gave. It would stand out a bit to be the only guy on a sportbike, but thats far from the end of the world.

Basically frendo, it all boils down to if you like the bike, it feels good between the legs, it won't run you out of money on insurance, and has been taken care of. If the ninja fits those characteristics then go for it, its a cut and dry starter/commuter bike.

>pic related
Maintenance day ran a bit long, and it gets dark here early damnit. Also proves I have some semblance of knowing about ninjas seeing as i actually own one.

How the computer emissions tests work is by checking that a) you don't have any trouble codes for emissions related systems and b)all monitors are set. These monitors are tests your car runs to make sure things are working, they take a bit of driving before they complete and they reset to "not ready" after codes are cleared. In most states, if your car is a certain age, you are allowed to have 1 to 2 monitors as "not ready" and still pass.

2UZ is one of the most reliable engines ever made. Just do the belt every 100k.
Every mechanic has worked on a 4runner, FJ, tundra, and sequoia before so there's no issue working on a 470 since they're the same. If you get an 04 it doesn't have an interference engine so losing a timing belt doesn't fuck shit up. It also doesn't have the Gucci sound system which while good is expensive to fix; make sure you check it by turning on the FM radio and messing w the volume, if it crackles then pass on it.
Check the center diff works because it's $35 to $3500 to fix depending on if you do the o rings in the actuator yourself or take it to the dealer and they put a whole new TC in.
The couple other small issues weren't changed in the 460.
Oh I forgot the main reason to get the 470 is it was made before Obama ruined cars.

>>26148480
A lot of people have gone the RZR (or equivalent) by me and are selling off mild build XJ's like that pic. If it were a full crawler build and priced something like that I'd say run, but for what he's listed it seems about right. If there's no pics of the unibody or if it looks like some stiffeners have been added over rust you need to do some real investigation, but as alway with Jeeps, if it's not rusted and it's running it's probably fine. That said, if you have no mechanical knowledge and are looking at purchasing something this old, with that many miles, that's obviously been off-roaded be prepared to get raped by a mechanic or learn to wrench. I actually learned on a YJ with the same 4.0 and it was an awesome way to break into shade tree mechanic stuff because it's so dead simple and cheap to repair. Go give it a look, take a ton of pics, and if you have more questions post them to an XJ forum if you want help, or here if you want to be called a fag and maybe be given some help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The only good independent radio that exists now anywhere is on AM. After deregulation, clearchannel bought pretty much everything fm and turned it into syndicated garbage to sell ads. Thats why you have so many classic rock stations with the same 100 songs in heavy rotation. Your iheartmedia classic rock channel in Albuquerque is the same as in albany.

Some areas still have locally run am stations you can tune into with quirky shows and things that actually connect you to a place. Print and audio media consumption has rapidly turned into mass syndicated trash. Indy radio and AM, while dying, at least can represent a last grasp at something that once was great and unique to localities.

Thanks for reading my post.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26159699
>>26159716
>rust
Yes, W210s (along with 202s and late model 124s) did have tons of problems due to Mercedes' first time usage of water-based lacquers. To be more accurate: Bacteria developed in the lacquer pools. They changed the behavior of the lacquer so it hat a lower cohesion especially at very narrow parts like the underside of the doors.
That being said:
1) Not every 210 had this problem. The lacquer pools got refilled every week or other week. Only cars who went through the pool when the lacquer was already a few days old (= lots oc bacteria) had this problem.
2) Every 210 who had this problem has already rusted away many years ago. We are talking about the 00s and early 10s. Don't forget that the 210 only ran between 1995 and 2002.
So today there's honestly no reason to be overly afraid of rust since what's still left has a normal rust-level just like you'd expect from a 20+X years old car.
>>electronics are a mess
Somewhat true but then again: Every car's electronics are a mess if they have been designed and built so many decades ago.
>if you manage to preserve a good AMG
Most if not all AMGs on the market have had many users and are more than often beat to shit. Stay away from AMGs and other large displacement 210s.
>Is this a classic?
It depends who you ask. I for example really adore the lines of the 210, especially the rear part. But just like back in the days there are also lots of people who hate the headlight design.
It will be a good investment if you take care of it. They are still really cheap because they are too young to be considered real classics, unlike 124s. But I guess we're only a few years away from a time where 210s get that attention too.
Never forget: Back in the days NOBODY thought that 123s or 124s would become sought-after classics in the future. Now take a good look what you gotta pay for a plain jane 124 station wagon for example. Not even talking about the Coupe.
t. former 210 owner.

From an American perspective, they are simply ok. Kinda ugly and with known quality issues relating from electric, paint, and rust. If you find a solid one, it will last fucking forever, but you really need to make sure it was taken care of prior to your ownership. They are the last dependable Merc and also fairly affordable. I’ve seen as low as 5k for a decent condition e420 with ~120k on the clock, but that was pre-pandemic. I haven’t looked at prices since. My biggest recommendation is find a reputable specialist shop only for old Mercs and utilize them frequently. These cars are simple to repair in theory, but if you find a repair beyond your skill level, nothing kills these cars quicker than a hack repair

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
i have an '01 e320 wagon with a v6 m112. 210k miles.

inherited from my parents. they did their work on it, but let me tell you what's failed on it so far:

valve cover gaskets leaked, replaced with OEM. resealed breather covers, replaced hoses. replaced air filter and intake seal to throttle body.

rear window regulator has gone out 3 times. each time you gotta punch out the old rivets, and try to get it to line up. I don't use the rear windows EVER.

recently, the serp belt tensioner went out, did not notice because the ball bearing was hidden between it and the block. going 90mph on the highway, my drive belt goes out and shreds. engine overheats slightly, had to get towed back to the house.

replace tensioner, belt, idler pulley. coolant boiled out when it overheat, replace that

3 days later going to dentists, engine stalls on me. figure out its the crank pos sensor, killed from the overheat prior. replace, stalls stop.

currently prepareing to swap the outer tie rod ends, lower control arm ball joints and sway bar linkages on both sides.

can confirm the rust, the paint sucks. the plastic is very brittle in these and over time everything starts to crack.

however, lots of space. would recocmmend the sedan though, the wagon/estate is a bit heavy for my liking.

Nissan has bungled its exit from the FIA World Endurance championship as badly as it handled competing in the fiercely competitive sports cars series.

Approximately 40 employees at the Indianapolis-based LMP1 program were notified by e-mail the program had been cancelled Tuesday morning, yet with many of the staffers on vacation for the holidays and away from work e-mail, news of the firing, for some, came from a press release the Japanese brand decided to post in its global newsroom. Those who did turn up for work Tuesday morning were barred access to the building, and senior team officials, who were also caught by surprise, stepped in to call and inform (or confirm) the sudden dismissals for all who worked at the facility.

Nissan's cancelation of the troubled program, just days before Christmas, is the latest chapter in what has been a truly tumultuous journey from concept to race.

Road & Track was present for the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO's debut on Dec. 19, 2014, at Circuit of The Americas, where the radical, front-engine, front-wheel-drive prototype suffered through a troubled introduction that made only modest gains over the next 368 days until the program's termination. https://www.roadandtrack.com/motorsports/news/a27710/nissan-fired-its-lmp1-employees-over-e-mail/

>>26075559
Pretty much..
“Behind the engine and beneath the cockpit is a kinetic energy recovery system using two flywheels developed by Torotrak. The flywheels gain energy from the use of the front brakes then discharges that energy back to the front wheels via a driveshaft running over the top of the combustion engine. The flywheels can also output power to a secondary driveshaft which is connected to a limited-slip differential at the rear of the car which feeds epicyclic gearboxes located in each rear wheel hub, allowing the GT-R to be all-wheel drive if necessary.”

Sound complicated? It should, because it is.

Additionally, while the engine is in front of the driver, it’s also behind the centerline of the front wheels, so it’s more of a front-mid layout. As Bowlby explained in an interview with Racecar Engineering:

“The front tyres on the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO are bigger than the rear tyres – 14 inch wide front vs. 9 inch rear. This is due to the way that mass is distributed in the car. We have moved the weight bias forwards to give us traction for the front-engined, front-wheel drive. We’ve also moved the aero forwards so we’ve moved the capacity of the tyres forward to match the weight distribution. So the aero centre of pressure, the mass centre of gravity and the tyre capacity are all in harmony and that means we have bigger tyres at the front than the rear”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26068883
Mitsubishi Motors completely abandoned RWD cars with the exception of the Starion in the 1980s. This would be one of the many decisions that would bleed the brand over the next few decades.
When the big three of Japan decided to come out with their bespoke luxury brands, Mitsubishi decided there was no need for this despite having basically no clout in the American market, they made fleet and commuter vehicles. This combined with the pathetic 3.0 V6 meant the gussies up Galant known as the Sigma was a failure.
They also gradually fucked up their sports car lineup in the states as well. The DSM cars, Chrysler's FWD sports cars, and the captive import Starion (Chrysler Conquest), occupied slightly varying price levels but were essentially in competition with each other in the same showrooms.
The GTO/3000GT used a twin-turbo version of the 6G72 3.0 V6 in the highest trims. We know now that even this engine struggled to power the AWD system of the over 3500 lb car which wasn't helped by the two turbochargers. What's stranger is that the 6G74 3.5 V6 was dropped in multiple Mitsubishi vehicles, SUVs and sedans, and was able to approach the twin-turbo 6G72 in power in NA form.
During the height of the Fast and Furious tuner hype, Mitsubishi cut corners and made the third generation Eclipse FWD only, but let you have a V6.
The company would spend the 2000s and 2010s producing shitty commuter cars for the states, the market they invested so much into entering through the Chrysler partnership. By the 2010s they were essentially a second class Jap brand like Suzuki and Isuzu.

Bonded title where I live requires you to get a bond for the value of the vehicle with the state. Then the state researches the vehicle to prove it's clear and ready to register. The state obviously has a record of registered vehicles. But without a title, they have to check and see if the vehicle has been reported stolen anywhere and that takes time.
i.e. if you live in bumblefuck county florida but you're on vacation to cousinfucker county alabama and your car gets stolen, you'd file the police report with the cousinfucker county sheriff's department because that's where the crime happened. It's most likely not going to automatically get reported back to bumblefuck county or to the state of florida as a stolen car because there's no national database for that sort of thing.

>Your shitbox will never need a race clutch
My shitbox came with 300Nm of torque from factory, based on the stuff I've done, such as straight pipe, intercooler, air intake, it should be outputting around 450. It did ~415 on the dyno with just a remap and stock parts.
Now, the stock clutch handles only 330Nm maximum. There's a reinforced one that can handle 540, however if I upgrade the turbo, headers, downpipe and intake manifold and bump up the boost pressure, it may well go over 540Nm of torque.
So yeah it will need a race clutch. Because it's the only one that can handle the torque and bolts onto the stock flywheel.
>You're not dumping the clutch at redline with drag slicks on the way to work.
And that's exactly why I asked if it would even work to drive normally on a race clutch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26165521
>And that's exactly why I asked if it would even work to drive normally on a race clutch.

A 4-puck will make you absolutely miserable every single day, especially if you've got a boosted engine where torque starts coming on above 2500. They are meant to engage hard and fast, which is great for racing, but driving in stop-and-go traffic is agony. Also the lack of slip means if your rev matching's off, you are making synchros do a lot more work. A 6-puck could be barely tolerable, but honestly it won't be. They're just shit on street cars.

Find a full-face/flywheel combo that can handle the torque, or recognize that you're essentially building a race car that won't be streetable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26165464
Ok here's the thing with clutches. A general rule of thumb is that the more torque a clutch can handle, the harder it is to drive smoothly. The distance between spinning freely and locked up will become razor thin, and it's gonna grab very hard. It can be done, but it'll suck. A high-end clutch from a reputable manufacturer will be much nicer to drive than a cheaper one rated for a similar amount of torque, but even so it won't be pleasant. Don't get an unnecessarily strong clutch, and don't cheap out on it either. I'd advice against a puck style clutch if you can get the desired torque rating in a traditional disc clutch.

I have a sprung puck clutch in my Focus and it's very streetable. It has some chatter sure but it's really not noticeable unless you're looking for it. My friend has an unsprung 6 puck in his s4 and it is very obnoxious, not really an issue where we are but definitely not something I would want to sit in traffic in; that said you don't notice it once you're rolling and shifting gears.

If you can get a sprung disc (ie, you won't be doing ridiculous launches where longevity of the hub is a concern), get it, as it will drastically improve streetability.

This is the way to go if you can get it. Twin disc kevlar clutches have all the streetability of a normal clutch with all the extra torque capacity. Audi used a factory twin disc setup on their 3.0tdis in the 2010s.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26155512
International is the cheap fleet truck, they’re shitty. Everything is plastic and the smell of the plastic offgassing is so bad that you need to park with the windows open the first year of the truck’s life

Freightliner is probably #2 from the bottom. They’re solid company trucks, better than International, but nothing special. They might give you one piece of fake wood trim across the dash.

Kenworth is like Peterbilt Jr, the company doesn’t mind spending a couple extra bucks to have good lookin trucks on the road. Our Kenworths are way more comfy than Internationals of the same era.

Peterbilt is like Kenworth but even more of the Murrican Trucker. Tons of gauges with chrome rings around them, for owner-ops and companies that want to have lots of chrome on the road.

Western Star is a more rare one, all custom built trucks, like Peterbilt but more exclusive for the real super truckers.

Volvo is like if Freightliner cared about drivers. I love driving Volvos, lots of extra little touches, like Peterbilt but with a modern Yuro touch. Not sure if servicing them is so easy though.

Mack is a real small market share these days, not sure what happened to them. I saw like zero new Macks between 2000 and maybe 2015. They’re about on par with Kenworth, some chrome and not the cheapest looking, but they’re like 1% or less of trucks on the road so probably not great if you need service in the middle of the country.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26160054
>Basically all railroad development died after 1900
The vast majority of urban centers in the US existed by 1900.

>the car industry lobbied so fucking hard to build roads and highways.
That didn't really happen until the mid 20th century.

>This is an absolute farce to say that it was built around railroads because they're fucking garbage
Its not. Take a look at a map and look at the number of towns connected by rail. Most small towns in the US have abandoned railroad stations.

>it takes WEEKS sometimes to cross the country by rail.
That's because railroad companies were allowed to go freight-only, while still maintaining full control of the rails. As a result rail infrastructure in the US has only been required to meet the needs of bulk freight service, and Amtrak has to give right of way to freight on all but a tiny number of regional links.
Even today, we're not really talking about high speed rail as a cross-country service. But expanding the number of higher speed regional rail links. Not even proper high-speed rail, just slightly faster than highway travel.

As a car guy, if I could go the rest of my life not having to drive into Chicago because the rail service was functional again, that would be great.

posts.com: At what price of a car do you draw the line between getting only traffic insurance and getting full insurance? I don't know how it is in other countries but in Sweden you have to have "traffic insurance" to be allowed to drive the car and then optionally you can get "half insurance" or "full insurance".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164375
10 grand

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164375
20 grand
In Germany you got three insurance tiers
>Tier 1: Haftpflichtversicherung
This is the mandated minimum. i.e. you must have this ensurance otherwise you won't be able to register the car at all. This insurance only covers damages of the other party and third persons.
>Tier 2: Teilkaskoversicherung
Tier 1 plus some damages to your own car you were not responsible for. Glass damages, theft, robbery, burglary, animal-vehicle crashes and weather-related damages (e.g. flooding, hail etc.)
>Tier 3: Vollkaskoversicherung
Tiers 1 + 2 plus every other damage to your own car even if you were at fault.
Note: Tiers 2 and 3 usually may be
deductible. So you need to pay a certain sum (usually no more than 500 Euros) yourself and the insurance only covers the rest.

I'm honest, I don'live up to my own standards. My truck was 25k but I only got tier 1 insurance because I work remote and only drive like 2,000 miles per year - maximum. The higher tiers would be too expensive considering the low risk.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26161564
>>plastic everything
Cars have had plastic since the 1960s. Is there something about new plastics that's worse than old?

>>obviously designed with planned obsolescence in mind
Compared to what time period? Up until very recently, a car was obsolete the moment it rolled off the assembly line. "Want a new feature? Buy a new car" has been the standard since the beginning of cars. It's only recently that cars have been able to be software updated (and even more recently OTA updated) so the car you buy today can be relevant for longer than just the model year it was built. Planned obsolescence is the idea that the manufacturer already has a plan for how long they're going to support their products until they don't anymore. Tesla still updates the original 2012 Model S software. How long in your mind should a company support a product? Is 10 years enough? 20 years?

>>every component of the car is in communication with the computer, making basic work more difficult
It also makes diagnosing certain problems easier.

>>objectively shit designs and proportions because of safety regs
That's subjective. The lower risk of injury and death that you have driving a more modern car is objective, however.

>>tons of interference from nanny systems
Many can be turned off. Some can be useful and might save your life one day.

I'm not opposed to EV, I will get a cybertruck if they ever make one. It's not like ICE will go away any time soon. Besides, I have a country place no one knows about. It used to be a farm before the motor law. On sundays my nephew will elude the Eyes and hop the turbine freight. He will come outside the wire where I will await.

My nephew will get to experience the turbo slow to cross the borderline, and excitement will shiver up and down his spine as he runs like the wind. I will keep my car as new, for it is my dearest dream.

Hiding it under debris inside the barn, a brilliant red Mustang from a better, vanished time. Firing up that ICE engine, and it responds with a roar. The tires will spit gravel, and he can commit his weekly crime.

The leather will be well weathered, the hot metal and oil will scent the country air. The sunlight will reflect off the chrome, and the landscape will blur - every nerve aware.

Perhaps a gleaming alloy electric car will shoot toward him, two lanes wide. He can spin it around with shrieking tires, and run the deadly race. Screaming through the valley as another joins the chase.

He will come upon the one lane bridge, and leave the giant EV's stranded at the riverside. He will race back to the farm, and we can dream by the fireside.

I got pic related for $7 on clearance at Walmart and it might be my most used meter because it’s in my go-bag that gets tossed around. Still works good.
